nodes.title: Week 8: Intelligence & Testing

typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the eighth week of the course!

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 7, Sections 7.4 to 7.6) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.

It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

typeData.textContent: The first ever modern intelligence test in history was developed by Alfred Binet (1857-1911) and Theodore Simon (1873-1961) in the year of 1904. The French Ministry of Education asked these two researchers to develop a test that could distinguish mentally retarded children from the normally intelligent, however lazy children. The result became what's known as the Simon-Binet IQ test. The test consists of many components including logical reasoning, finding rhyming words, and naming objects. The score for the test combined with a child's age provides information on the intellectual development of said child, and the IQ score is calculated via the formula (mental age/chronological age)x100. The test was a huge success both in Europe and in America.

nodes.title: The History of Intelligence Testing

typeData.textContent:
Paul Broca (1824-1880) and Sir Francis Galton (1822-1911) were among the very first scientists to contemplate the measurement of intelligence. They came up with the idea of determining intelligence by measuring the size of the human skull. The larger the skull, the smarter the person. 

At around the same time, Wilhelm Wundt (1932-1920) used introspection to measure intelligence. Introspection is the human ability to reflect on their own thoughts. 

Nowadays, these methods of measuring intelligence are considered outdated and are no longer used for intelligence testing. However they were a fundamental part of the history of intelligence testing.

nodes.title: The History of Intelligence Testing - Li Nan Qiu

typeData.textContent:
Interest in intelligence and intelligence testing dates back to thousands of years ago. Paul Broca (1824-1880) and Sir Francis Galton (1822-1911) were among the very first scientists to contemplate the measurement of intelligence. They came up with the idea of determining intelligence by measuring the size of the human skull. The larger the skull, the smarter the person. 

At around the same time, Wilhelm Wundt (1932-1920) used introspection to measure intelligence. Introspection is the human ability to reflect on their own thoughts. 

Nowadays, these methods of measuring intelligence are considered outdated and are no longer used for intelligence testing. However they were a fundamental part of the history of intelligence testing.

Psychologist Alfred Binet was asked by the French government to identify students who needed educational assistance in school, because the government had passed laws requiring all French children to attend school. Binet and Theodore Simon, his colleague, then began developing questions that focused on attention, memory, and problem solving skills. Binet determined the ones who had predictors of school success through those questions. He realized that some of the children were able to answer more advanced questions, and based on the observation suggested the concept of mental age--a measure of intelligence based on children of a certain age group's average abilities. 

The first intelligence test that was then developed is known as the Binet-Simon Scale, and created considerable interest upon being introduced to the United States. Stanford psychologist Lewis Terman took the original test and standardized it with a sample of American participants. The adapted test is called the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale--the standard intelligence test used to U.S. The test uses a single number, the intelligence quotient (IQ) to represent a person's score. Since then the test has gone through several revisions but still remains a popular tool for intelligence assessment. 

Another intelligence test was created by American psychologist David Wechsler based on the Stanford-Binet test. Like Binet, Wechsler believed that intelligence involves several different mental abilities. But he was dissatisfied with the Stanford-Binet test's limitations. He published a new intelligence test known as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) in the year 1955. He also created two different tests for children: the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) and the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI). The adult version is now known as WAIS-IV. 

WAIS-IV contains 10 subtests as well as five supplemental tests. The test produces scores in 4 major areas of intelligence: verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed. The test also gives two broad scores as a summary for overall intelligence. The full IQ score combines performance on the four index scores. The General Ability Index being based on six subtest scores. Subtest scores have been proven useful for identifying learning disabilities.

nodes.title: The History of IQ Testing - Li Nan Qiu

typeData.textContent:
The first ever modern intelligence test in history was developed by Alfred Binet (1857-1911) and Theodore Simon (1873-1961) in the year of 1904. The French Ministry of Education asked these two researchers to develop a test that could distinguish mentally retarded children from the normally intelligent, however lazy children. The result became what's known as the Simon-Binet IQ test. The test consists of many components including logical reasoning, finding rhyming words, and naming objects. The score for the test combined with a child's age provides information on the intellectual development of said child, and the IQ score is calculated via the formula (mental age/chronological age)x100. The test was a huge success both in Europe and in America. 

There are pros and cons to IQ testing that have been proven throughout history. During the outset of World War I, US army officials had to screen an enormous number of recruits. Psychologist Robert Yerkes developed two tests: the Army Alpha and Beta tests. The Army Alpha test is a written test, whereas the Army Beta test is made up of pictures for those unable to read or those who didn't speak English. The tests were taken by over 2 million soldiers in an attempt to determine which men were suited to certain positions and leadership roles. The test continued to be used in a wide range of situations outside of military. This is when problems arose. The tests were used to screen immigrants entering the United States. Unfortunately the results were used to make inaccurate, sweeping generalizations about whole populations, leading to immigration restrictions.

nodes.title: History of Intelligent Testing (Crystal Li)
What is Dyscalculia? IQ and Learning Disabilities (Jenny Wong)
nodes.description: In our readings we have learned about the various types of learning disabilities such as dyslexia and dysgraphia. Here I will be explaining about a learning disability known as dyscalculia and the relation between IQ levels.

typeData.textContent:
There is a common misconception that all patients with a learning disability would also have a low IQ measurement. This is incorrect. An example of this would be patients with dyscalculia. People diagnosed with dyscalculia are unable to process the meaning of numbers and as a result completing mathematical problems is a very challenging task (Butterworth, 5). This disability is independent of IQ. Studies have shown that IQ level is not a good predictor of one’s mathematical abilities. It is possible for people with high IQ levels to be dyscalculic (Butterworth, 8). Patients with dyscalculia could have normal cognitive abilities such as the ability to reason and memorize information, but they cannot deal with anything related to numbers. The opposite also exists where patients can complete complex arithmetic calculations but may have trouble with their memory and language processing (Butterworth, 108). 

Dyscalculia lasts throughout one’s life. It can occur due to brain damage or genetic reasons. There are two types of dyscalculia: developmental dyscalculia and acquired acalculia. Developmental dyscalculia is believed to be due to genetic or congenital disorders (Butterworth, 2). Acquired acalculia is due to brain injury (Butterworth, 108). There are also social factors that contribute to dyscalculia such as a child’s socio-economic environment (Haberstroh et al. 2019). The prevalence rate is approximately three to seven percent in the general population (Haberstroh et al. 2019). This rate varies between different countries. Some common symptoms of this disability are difficulty reading clocks, unable to do subtraction, addition, etc. As a result, people with this disability often face impairments in school and at work. 

Two important brain structures that are vital for the processing of numbers are the right and left parietal lobes and the frontal lobe. Damage to the parietal lobes will cause a person to be unable to make numerical estimations, unable to do familiar arithmetic calculations and other basic calculations (Butterworth, 75). The frontal lobe is important for solving new mathematical problems that a person has not encountered before. (Butterworth, 75) The brains of dyscalculics often have problems in activation and abnormal structure in the parietal lobes (Butterworth, 91). 

There are interventions in place to prevent dyscalculia from getting worse. Some researchers suggest teaching children about numbers using sets (Butterworth, 146). For example, the number four is composed of 1,1,1, and 1 or 2 and 2. To demonstrate this, rather than using numbers, the teacher could use blocks to show what the number physically looks like. Starting off with concrete material allows for dyscalculics to visualize what numbers represent. Researchers emphasize that gradual progress is the most important and to teach the numerical concept in small steps (Butterworth, 153). After teaching the concrete representations, abstract concepts should be taught such as mathematical symbols and numbers. The inability to understand numbers often causes children to have low self-esteem. There is evidence that proves that anxiety hinders the working memory capacity which contributes to the inability to solve mathematical problems (Butterworth, 156). Therefore, a comfortable environment is especially important to help reduce anxiety. Intervention can only help reduce the severity of dyscalculia and unfortunately a cure does not exist. 

References 

Butterworth, B., 2019. Dyscalculia: from science to education. Routledge, London.

Haberstroh, S., Schulte-Körne, G., 2019. The diagnosis and treatment of dyscalculia. Deutsches  
            Aerzteblatt Online. doi:10.3238/arztebl.2019.0107

nodes.title: Gardner's Multiple Intelligences Quiz [Shawna Naderi]
Causes of the Flynn Effect (Shawna Naderi)
Types of Learning Disabilities (Taylor Swift-LaPointe)
nodes.description: The types of learning disabilities, including dysgraphia, dyslexia, dyscalculia, and the related disorder ADHD.

typeData.textContent:
Learning disabilities are cognitive disorders that inhibit an individual’s ability to learn, particularly involving reading and language (OpenStax 2018; NILD Canada 2019). A learning disability has no effect on intelligence – an individual with a learning disability may be misclassified as intellectually disabled on an IQ test, when in fact most people with learning disabilities have average to superior intelligence (OpenStax). Most learning disabilities are due to genetic mutations, often inherited from parents, but they can also be caused by head injuries during or after birth. Environmental factors during childhood do not cause learning disabilities, but they may enhance its effects if a child does not receive the necessary support in its learning (NILD Canada 2019).

There are several nationally recognized learning disabilities, and this post covers dysgraphia, dyslexia, dyscalculia, and the related disorder ADHD (which is not a learning disability). 

Dysgraphia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "graphia" = writing (NILD Canada)
Dysgraphia is characterized by the inability to write legibly and properly. An individual with dysgraphia struggles with the motor skills of physically writing with a pen or pencil. It is also associated with difficulties with other spatial abilities (OpenStax 2018).

Dyslexia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "lexia" = words
Dyslexia includes the inability to read words correctly, spell words, and manipulate sounds when reading words (NILD Canada 2019). It stems from difficulty in sound processing of letters in words. An individual with dyslexia may struggle with spelling, including mixing up the order of letters in words, word recognition, and reading (OpenStax 2018; Learning Disabilities Association 2013).

Dyscalculia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "calculia" = calculations and mathematics
Dyscalculia is a disability that causes difficulties in understanding numbers, including representation of numbers and processing of numbers (Learning Disabilities Association 2013). This results in problems with mathematics calculations (NILD Canada 2019). Dyscalculia has also been associated with difficulties in quantitative reasoning (Learning Disabilities Association 2013).

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
ADHD is not a learning disability, although 30-50% of children in the United States who have ADHD also have a learning disability. ADHD is a disorder characterized by hyperactivity, short attention spans, and difficulty staying focused on the task at hand (Learning Disabilities Association 2013).


References
Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). ADHD. Learning Disabilities Association of America. https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/adhd/

Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). Dyscalculia. Learning Disabilities Association of America. https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/dyscalculia/

Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). Dyslexia. Learning Disabilities Association of America.
https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/dyslexia/

NILD Canada. (2019). Learning Disabilities. National Institute for Learning Development. https://nildcanada.org/learning-disabilities/

OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018. http://cnx.org/contents/4abf04bf-93a0-45c3-9cbc-2cefd46e68cc@9.30

Discussing Gardner’s Multiple Intelligences (Amy Ly & Brent McLean)
nodes.description: A discussion on Howard Gardner’s multiple intelligence theory and possible other intelligences. We will discuss the benefits and critiquing this theory of intelligence.

typeData.textContent:
Howard Gardner disagreed with unitary intelligence and developed the idea of multiple intelligences to represent different abilities among individuals. The main eight intelligence types he presented included: Visual-spatial, linguistic-verbal, interpersonal, intrapersonal, logical-mathematical, musical, bodily-kinesthetic and naturalistic.

Critique (Amy Ly):

From observation, these eight intelligences are theoretical and cannot be falsified. How is it possible to show an individual’s intrapersonal intelligence? What could possibly be used as measurement and what would be identified as moderate level of intrapersonal intelligence or the norm? These are my personal critiques which I’m sure are shared by others. From a simple google, researchers have also argued that the proposed intelligences are “talents, personality traits, and abilities” that do not represent intelligence.

In an article written by John White (2006), he explains how Gardner come up with this theory of multiple intelligences. White claims that Gardner came up with these eight types of intelligence not from scientific reasoning, but using his own personal judgement. Gardner created these intelligences by categorizing activities he considered culturally important, such as dance, mathematics and painting. Also, these categories Gardner came up with are arbitrary in nature as he has no scientific reasoning behind them besides preference. White goes on to explain how Gardner assessed his multiple intelligence in an individual and quotes Gardner as saying “a candidate’s intelligence is reminiscent more of an artistic judgment than of a scientific assessment”. This quote shows that there is no scientific background or merit to Gardner’s theory of multiple intelligences as there is no scientific reasoning/experiment or a reliable and valid method to test the eight intelligences in this theory.

Benefits of this theory: (Brent McLean)
One of the most obvious benefits to Gardner’s multiple intelligence theory is how it allows for the branching towards a more expanded definition of intelligence. Having eight different types of intelligence allows for the expansion of what we can define as intelligence. We no longer have to perceive intelligence solely based on the empirical merits of performance in academic or professional settings. Rather, intelligence can be described categorically using Gardner’s theory. As each type of intelligence covers a unique perspective and ability, the consideration of who is considered intelligent is expanded using this theory. This has the potential to have positive social impact as we can be cognitively assessed and labeled by our natural abilities rather than assessed by the rather dulling and standardized method of the classic education system. To paint a picture, on a different scale with the same principle: an monkey ranks well below an eagle in its ability to fly but that’s not to say that the monkey is any less viable of an animal in it’s abilities. As quoted by one of the most influential people of all time:

“Everybody is a genius. But if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.” – Albert Einstein

This quote has provoking abilities in discussing the revaluation of how we define intelligence. Although largely theoretical and unproven, Howard Gardner’s theory on multiple intelligence’s has the ability to reduce the unequal scale of intelligence and better represent individuals abilities in a more detailed manner on a wider range of intelligence that our society could greatly benefit from if researched and expanded upon further.

Discussing Unofficial Intelligence Types Proposed by Gardner (Amy Ly & Brent McLean):
As discussed previously, Gardner came up with the eight intelligences simply due to preference. Although not discussed thoroughly in class lectures, he also proposed a few more possible intelligences one could possess. Listed below are some intelligences that he suggested:

    Existential Intelligence – Individual’s ability to use collective values and intuition to understand others and the world around them
    Humor Intelligence
    Memory Intelligence
    Teaching-Pedagogical Intelligence – Teaching other people successfully
    Spiritual Intelligence
    Existential Intelligence
    Moral Intelligence

The reason these did not get included into his theory is hypothesized that they did not meet his personal criteria for what intelligence was.

References

White, J., (2006). The trouble with multiple intelligences. [Forum]. Teaching Geography. https://www.geography.org.uk/download/ga_prgtipwhite2006.pdf

nodes.title: Sternberg's Theory of Intelligence (Tom Li)

typeData.textContent:
In the late 1900’s, the American psychologist Robert Sternberg, proposed that intelligence is comprised of three parts: practical, analytical and creative intelligence. Sternberg titled these three forms of intelligence as the “Triarchic Theory of Intelligence.” Sternberg’s theory provides a broader conceptualization of intelligence in comparison to most conventional or traditional theories.

Practical intelligence involves the person to find practical solutions by applying experience-based or “tactical knowledge” to everyday problems (Sternberg, 1985). This knowledge is often never explicitly taught in academia or verbalized (Sternberg, 1985). Therefore, this type of intelligence is sometimes referred to as “street smart.” Sternberg measured this type of intelligence by providing subjects with work-related issues that are commonly encountered in a number of jobs (Sternberg, 1985). These participants are then required to assess and rate the quality of a number of solutions for each problem (Sternberg, 1985). However, an individual that scores high in practical intelligence may not translate to having a high IQ score in traditional intelligence tests. Additionally, these individuals may or may not excel in analytical or creative intelligence. 

Analytical intelligence on the other hand, involves an ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast. As such, individuals that score high in this category would tend to excel academically in problem solving, computations, and literature. One method Sternberg used to test this type of intelligence was by measuring the individual’s information-processing components (Sternberg, 1985). This consisted of an “encoding component” and a “inference component” (Sternberg, 1985). The “encoding component” is the individual’s ability to understand the definition of a word, while the “inference component” refers to the subject’s ability to relate other words to the previously presented word that they were required to define (Sternberg, 1985).  

Lastly, creative intelligence involves imagination or creating nuanced solutions for a problem or a situation. This type of intelligence can also be marked by creative art works or inventions. Therefore, Sternberg tested creative intelligence by having his participants create products that involved writing, advertising, art, and science (Sternberg, 1985).

References
Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Beyond IQ: A triarchic theory of human intelligence. CUP Archive.

nodes.title: IQ Testing in the Medical Field (sierra labron)
Applications of intelligence testing: Military [Lukas Franz]
nodes.description: a quick look at military uses of intelligence testing

typeData.textContent:
From our readings and lectures, we know that military bodies employed intelligence testing, in various forms. The United States initially used Robert Yerkes’ army alpha and army beta tests developed in World War 1 to determine the intelligence of their recruits.
The readings and lectures did not go into any more detail. From a little extra research, it turns out the scores of these tests used to see if recruits were mentally fit to be active in the forces and discover those who would be good candidates for military academies or officer-training schools (Brandwein, 2011). If done effectively this methodology provides a better way of selecting higher-ups than the previous method of officers promoting whomever they see fit regardless of actual merit.

In the United States, intelligence tests are still carried out for military recruits however according to a 2007 archive of a recruitment website they students are now required to take a test called the CAT-ASVAB.

Works cited

 Brandwein, D. (2011). Army Alpha Intelligence Test. Encyclopedia Of Child Behavior And Development, 142-143. doi: 10.1007/978-0-387-79061-9_182

Web archive:
USMEPCOM Your Future Begins Now, Testing Archived March 20, 2007, at the Wayback Machine
Actual link: https://web.archive.org/web/20070320234448/http://www.mepcom.army.mil/visitor-info.asp

nodes.title: Applications of Intelligence Testing: Income [Lukas Franz]
IQ and Job Performance (Teresa Liao)

typeData.textContent:
History
Prior to the 1970s, hundreds of studies reported low correlations (0.2-0.3) between IQ tests and job performance. Schmidt and Hunter suspected that the “large quantity of results were attenuated by various statistical artifacts, including sampling error, unreliability of measuring instruments, and restriction of range” (Richardson & Norgate, 2015, p.155). The two created methods to correct the artifacts and the correlation was corrected to approximately 0.5. Many studies and meta-analyses since then have made strong connections between IQ and job performance (e.g. Ree & Earles, 1992; Schmidt, 2002).

Explanation
The consensus on why IQ is predicative of job performance is that people who are more intelligent learn the job relevant knowledge more quickly and in depth, resulting in better job performance (e.g. Hunter, 1986; Ree et al., 1995). The correlation could also be due to self-fulfilling prophecies, where the employer’s expectation causes the success of the employee through additional resource allocation (Byington & Felps, 2010).  

Emotional Intelligence (EI)
Many studies have shown that EI is predicative of job performance with some studies indicating a correlation of approximately 0.24 to 0.30 (O’Boyle et al., 2011). Research also suggest that people with high levels of emotional intelligence cope effectively with high demands and stress which leads to better job performance and less job burnout (Gong, Chen, & Wang, 2019; Moon & Hur, 2011). Côté and Miners (2006) on the other hand, found evidence that in terms of job performance, low cognitive intelligence can be compensated by emotional intelligence. 


References 
Byington, E., Felps, W. (2010). Why do IQ scores predict job performance? Research in Organizational Behavior, 30, 175-202. doi:10.1016/j.riob.2010.08.003

Côté, S., Miners, C. T. (2006). Emotional Intelligence, Cognitive Intelligence, and Job Performance. Administrative Science Quarterly, 51(1), 1-28. doi:10.2189/asqu.51.1.1

Gong, Z., Chen, Y., Wang, Y. (2019). The Influence of Emotional Intelligence on Job Burnout and Job Performance: Mediating Effect of Psychological Capital. Frontiers in Psychology, 10. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02707

Hunter, J. E. (1986). Cognitive ability, cognitive aptitudes, job knowledge, and job performance. Journal of Vocational Behavior, 29(3), 340-362. doi:10.1016/0001-8791(86)90013-8

Moon, T. W., Hur, W. (2011). Emotional Intelligence, Emotional Exhaustion, And Job Performance. Social Behavior and Personality: An International Journal, 39(8), 1087-1096. doi:10.2224/sbp.2011.39.8.1087

O'boyle, E. H., Humphrey, R. H., Pollack, J. M., Hawver, T. H., Story, P. A. (2011). The relation between emotional intelligence and job performance: A meta-analysis. Journal of Organizational Behavior, 32(5), 788-818. doi:10.1002/job.714

Ree, M. J., Earles, J. A. (1992). Intelligence Is the Best Predictor of Job Performance. Current Directions in Psychological Science, 1(3), 86-89. doi:10.1111/1467-8721.ep10768746

Ree, M. J., Carretta, T. R., Teachout, M. S. (1995). Role of ability and prior knowledge in complex training performance. Journal of Applied Psychology, 80(6), 721-730. doi:10.1037/0021-9010.80.6.721

Richardson, K., Norgate, S. H. (2015). Does IQ Really Predict Job Performance? Applied Developmental Science, 19(3), 153-169. doi:10.1080/10888691.2014.983635

Schmidt, F. L. (2002). The Role of General Cognitive Ability and Job Performance: Why There Cannot Be a Debate. Role of General Mental Ability in Industrial, Work, and Organizational Psychology, 187-210. doi:10.4324/9781410608802-12

nodes.title: IQ Testing Wrongly Invoked the Belief of Eugenics (Nathan Liminsang)
Howard Gardner's Multiple Intelligences Theory (Claudia Le)

typeData.textContent:
Developed by Howard Gardner, the Multiple Intelligences Theory describes how each person has at least 8 different intelligences. While everyone has the same intelligences, each person may excel more in a certain intelligence than others. 

Journalists, poets, and teachers excel in linguistic intelligence. They effectively express themselves in spoken and written language while some also show the ability to easily learn multiple languages. 

Those with high logical-mathematical intelligence have the ability to think logically and reason. People such as scientists and mathematicians easily see numerical patterns, identify solutions to problems, and work with abstract ideas. 

Musical intelligence refers to those who are capable of understanding pitch, rhythm, and tone. Composers and performers have skills such as recognizing notes and musical patterns, producing music, and distinguishing different instruments. 

People who excel in bodily kinesthetic intelligence can easily manipulate their body to perform tasks and move their bodies in certain ways. While some may use to skill to find a career in sports, many also become dancers and athletic coaches.

Choreographers, architects, and aviators have high spatial intelligence. People excelling in this skill are able to transform visual images and understand how objects move in space while also comprehending the relationship of these objects. 

Those who have high interpersonal intelligence may find themselves being a counselor, social worker, or salesperson. They are empathetic, being able to understand others' emotions and needs which may help them in social situations. 

In order to have some personal growth, one must excel in intrapersonal intelligence. Exploring one's inner personal feelings and putting them towards a goal to manage their life displays intrapersonal intelligence. One with high intrapersonal intelligence may have an idea of what they want their future to look like, they are highly motivated and know how they can achieve this goal. 

Biologists, ecologists, and environmentalists all excel in naturalist intelligence. They have the ability to appreciate the natural world and interact with objects, animals, and plants in the environment. This intelligence involves being sensitive to the world and may find a natural interest in the environment and weather. 

While the 8 intelligences listed above are distinct, interpersonal and intrapersonal intelligence are often combined to be called emotional intelligence. Having high emotional intelligence involves being able to respond to one's own and others' feelings effectively while showing empathy and being able to respond in culturally appropriate ways.

nodes.title: Reasons behind a consistent rise in our average IQ scores (Jingxin Guo)

typeData.textContent: why

nodes.title: The Anti-Flynn Effect (Sarah Wissmann)

typeData.textContent:
Researchers have spent years speculating the causes of the Flynn effect. However, recent evidence from several countries suggests that IQ has stagnated and may be declining. This has been called the anti-Flynn effect. Multilevel modelling has shown “that the anti-Flynn effect has strengthened in more recent years.” (Woodley of Menie, Peñaherrera-Aguirre, Fernandes, & Figueredo, 2018)
In some Scandinavian countries - specifically, Finland, Norway, and Denmark - average IQs have been dropping around 0.2 points per year. Woodley & Meissenburg (2013) suggest three possible reasons for this decline: 
1. Statistics: some objects referenced in tests are becoming obsolete, improper statistical sampling
2. Cultural - environmental: cultural and environmental circumstances are worsening (opposite of some explanations for the Flynn effect)
3. Biological: dysgenic biological factors - suggests that IQ may be an unfavourable trait when it comes to reproduction or intelligence is an irrelevant factor in reproduction.
	However, Woodley of Menie et al. (2018) have found no correlation between the anti-Flynn effect and the Index of Biological State (which measures selection operating on g), rather there seemed to be a higher correlation between the anti-Flynn effect and immigration. As seen in the past, immigrants are more likely to do worse on IQ tests which suggests a cultural bias to the tests that puts them at a disadvantage.
Robson (2019) has suggested this may be due to schools targeting different skills. For instance, math skills may be perceived as having worsened because of increased use of calculators in class. 
In summary, regardless of the reason for the anti-Flynn effect, it is important to note that this does not necessarily indicate that this generation is ‘dumber’ than previous generations. Rather, it more likely represents a cultural shift in behaviour/norms which implies that IQ tests should be constantly updated to take our changing world into account.

References: 
1. Meta Quest Clips. (23 Apr 2020). James Flynn: Why the Flynn Effect has Stopped in Scandanavia. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuUjjLL_GX4
2. Robson, D. (2019 July 9) Has humanity reached ‘peak intelligence’? Retrieved from https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20190709-has-humanity-reached-peak-intelligence
3. Woodley of Menie, M.A., Peñaherrera-Aguirre, M., Fernandes, H.B.F., & Figueredo, A.J. (2018). What causes the anti-Flynn effect? A data analysis and synthesis of predictors. Evolutionary Behavioural Sciences, 12(4), 276-295. http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/ebs0000106 
4. Woodley, M.A., & Meisenburg, G. (2013). In the Netherlands the anti-Flynn effect is a Jensen effect. ScienceDirect, 54(8), 871-876. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2012.12.022

nodes.title: IQ and Job Performance (Teresa Liao)

typeData.textContent:
History
Prior to the 1970s, hundreds of studies reported low correlations (0.2-0.3) between IQ tests and job performance. Schmidt and Hunter suspected that the “large quantity of results were attenuated by various statistical artifacts, including sampling error, unreliability of measuring instruments, and restriction of range” (Richardson & Norgate, 2015, p.155). The two created methods to correct the artifacts and the correlation was corrected to approximately 0.5. Many studies and meta-analyses since then have made strong connections between IQ and job performance (e.g. Ree & Earles, 1992; Schmidt, 2002).

Explanation
The consensus on why IQ is predicative of job performance is that people who are more intelligent learn the job relevant knowledge more quickly and in depth, resulting in better job performance (e.g. Hunter, 1986; Ree et al., 1995). The correlation could also be due to self-fulfilling prophecies, where the employer’s expectation causes the success of the employee through additional resource allocation (Byington & Felps, 2010).  

Emotional Intelligence (EI)
Many studies have shown that EI is predicative of job performance with some studies indicating a correlation of approximately 0.24 to 0.30 (O’Boyle et al., 2011). Research also suggest that people with high levels of emotional intelligence cope effectively with high demands and stress which leads to better job performance and less job burnout (Gong, Chen, & Wang, 2019; Moon & Hur, 2011). Côté and Miners (2006) on the other hand, found evidence that in terms of job performance, low cognitive intelligence can be compensated by emotional intelligence. 


References 
Byington, E., Felps, W. (2010). Why do IQ scores predict job performance? Research in Organizational Behavior, 30, 175-202. doi:10.1016/j.riob.2010.08.003

Côté, S., Miners, C. T. (2006). Emotional Intelligence, Cognitive Intelligence, and Job Performance. Administrative Science Quarterly, 51(1), 1-28. doi:10.2189/asqu.51.1.1

Gong, Z., Chen, Y., Wang, Y. (2019). The Influence of Emotional Intelligence on Job Burnout and Job Performance: Mediating Effect of Psychological Capital. Frontiers in Psychology, 10. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02707

Hunter, J. E. (1986). Cognitive ability, cognitive aptitudes, job knowledge, and job performance. Journal of Vocational Behavior, 29(3), 340-362. doi:10.1016/0001-8791(86)90013-8

Moon, T. W., Hur, W. (2011). Emotional Intelligence, Emotional Exhaustion, And Job Performance. Social Behavior and Personality: An International Journal, 39(8), 1087-1096. doi:10.2224/sbp.2011.39.8.1087

O'boyle, E. H., Humphrey, R. H., Pollack, J. M., Hawver, T. H., Story, P. A. (2011). The relation between emotional intelligence and job performance: A meta-analysis. Journal of Organizational Behavior, 32(5), 788-818. doi:10.1002/job.714

Ree, M. J., Earles, J. A. (1992). Intelligence Is the Best Predictor of Job Performance. Current Directions in Psychological Science, 1(3), 86-89. doi:10.1111/1467-8721.ep10768746

Ree, M. J., Carretta, T. R., Teachout, M. S. (1995). Role of ability and prior knowledge in complex training performance. Journal of Applied Psychology, 80(6), 721-730. doi:10.1037/0021-9010.80.6.721

Richardson, K., Norgate, S. H. (2015). Does IQ Really Predict Job Performance? Applied Developmental Science, 19(3), 153-169. doi:10.1080/10888691.2014.983635

Schmidt, F. L. (2002). The Role of General Cognitive Ability and Job Performance: Why There Cannot Be a Debate. Role of General Mental Ability in Industrial, Work, and Organizational Psychology, 187-210. doi:10.4324/9781410608802-12

nodes.title: Criticism of Howard Gardner’s Multiple Intelligences   Peri Sheppard

typeData.textContent:
Howard Garnder’s theory of multiple intelligences is a very popular theory of intelligences with tens of thousands of citations of his papers and books on google scholar, but it’s not without its issues. A large problem with Gardner’s theory is that there is a lack of empirical evidence supporting it. In fact there is evidence that Gardner’s intelligences correlate with each other and with the g factor (Visser, 2006) pointing away from the idea of distinct individual intelligences. There is also the difficulty that Gardner’s theories cannot be falsified. It’s not possible in many cases to discern whether something like musical ability is a result of aptitude or acquired purely through practice.(Visser, 2006)  Despite being heavily criticized the theory remains very popular in the field of education. (Haier, 2009) The idea that each individual is uniquely smart can be argued to have some societal value even though it’s not rigorously supported. (Gardner, 1993)


References
Gardner, H. (1993). Frames of mind. Basic Books.

Haier, R., Colom, R., Schroeder, D., Condon, C., Tang, C., Eaves, E., & Head, K. (2009). Gray matter and intelligence factors: Is there a neuro-g?. Intelligence, 37(2), 136-144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intell.2008.10.011

Visser, B., Ashton, M., & Vernon, P. (2006). g and the measurement of Multiple Intelligences: A response to Gardner. Intelligence, 34(5), 507-510. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intell.2006.04.006

nodes.title: The Evolution of Intelligence Theories (Brent McLean)
Sternberg's Triarchic Theory of Intelligence Video and Quiz
Sternberg's Triarchic Theory of Intelligence Video and Quiz (Tom Li)
The Heritability of Intelligence and affects of the Environment (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
The topic of Nature v Nurture in terms of intelligence has been debated. The idea that intelligence is part of an external locus of control due to genes can have demotivating effects on growth, though the idea of intelligence relating only to environmental factors conflicts with studies of the IQ of twins raised apart (Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990).
While studies have shown that intelligence can be inherited from parents (nature), environmental affects have shown changes on IQ (Bartels, Rietveld, Van Baal, & Boomsma, 2002). In the past, the idea of eugenics has played roles in enforcing beliefs in superiority through genes and have led to tragic consequences for many. A more correct modern idea of nature v nurture can be seen with the Range of Reaction theory in which an intelligence potential is set through genes and depended on environmental factors and their appraisals, the potential may or may not be met to varying degrees.
This theory was reaffirmed with evidence of studies by Csikszentmihalyi & Csikszentmihalyi, 1993. In which children from a strong genetic background were shown to be greatly affected by extent of stimulation from the environment.

nodes.title: Well Known Creative People with Mental Illnesses - Vivien Li
The Relationship Between Creativity and Mental Illness - Vivien Li
Synesthesia, Creativity, and Mental Illness [Rebecca Yang]
nodes.description:
The possibility of a third factor in the relationship between mental illness and creativity.

This node summarizes some research I have done on this notion, as well as some of my thoughts and inferences in relation to the course material.

typeData.textContent:
[DESCRIPTION: The possibility of a third factor in the relationship between mental illness and creativity.
This node summarizes some research I have done on this notion, as well as some of my thoughts and inferences in relation to the course material.]

Synesthesia is a primarily congenital neurological condition where sensory input in one modality elicits a sensory experience in another modality (Wendler and Schubert, 2019). For example, someone could experience seeing a particular colour in response to music, or taste flavours in response to reading certain words.

Synesthesia has been reported in many famous artists and musicians, including Pharrell Williams, Vincent van Gogh, and Franz Liszt (English, 2019). This suggests that synesthesia likely has a strong connection to creativity.

After investigating this phenomenon using an experiment that administered the Alternative Uses Test (ALT) and the Remote Association Test, or RAT (a measure of divergent thinking) to both a group of synesthetes and controls, a research team discovered that the synesthetes outperformed controls on the RAT, but not the ALT (Ward, Tompson-Lake, Ely, Kaminski, 2010). Upon further analysis of the results, it was concluded that synesthesia may enable one to be higher in certain, though not all, aspects of creativity. However, people with certain types of synesthesia were much more likely than the general population to be involved in the creative arts. In addition, it was stated that those who possessed the ability to synesthesia-like associations tended to also be high in creativity (Ward, Tompson-Lake, Ely, Kaminski, 2010).

However, other research has shown that synesthesia may not be solely beneficial, as many studies have suggested that it is also linked to the presence of various psychiatric illnesses, particularly anxiety (Carmichael et al, 2018), ASD (Carmichael, 2015), schizophrenia (Carmichael, 2015), and OCD (Wendler and Schubert, 2019). One researcher has proposed that because synesthesia affects serotonin transporters, they are at higher risk for psychiatric conditions that involve serotonin (Carmichael, 2015).

As the Openstax textbook states, certain psychiatric conditions likely do in fact result in higher levels of creativity. However, that does not omit the possibility of a second explanation, more specifically one that involves synesthesia. Perhaps, in some cases of individuals with mental illness, creativity may be enhanced by comorbid synesthesia, and some creative individuals with synesthesia may also have comorbid mental illness. 

I would also like to offer the idea that, maybe, in the case of schizophrenia, an increased likelihood of synesthesia may help to partly explain why it is present in relatives of the sufferer but not the sufferer themselves. I infer that the extremely impairing nature of schizophrenia may keep the sufferer from engaging in certain tasks, many of which may be creative. However, as synesthesia is largely genetic, relatives of the individual may be able to experience the creative advantages of synesthesia without the hindrance of schizophrenia.


References:

Carmichael, D. (2015, November 26). Synaesthesia and comorbidity. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from http://hdl.handle.net/1842/15796

English, T. (2019, October 28). 9 Famous Artists Who Have Synesthesia and How It Affected Them. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from https://interestingengineering.com/9-famous-artists-who-have-synesthesia-and-how-it-affected-them

Ward, J., Thompson-Lake, D., Ely, R., & Kaminski, F. (2008). Synaesthesia, creativity and art: What is the link? British Journal of Psychology, 99(1), 127-141. doi:10.1348/000712607x204164

Wendler, E., & Schubert, E. (2019). Synaesthesia, Creativity and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Is There a Link? Creativity Research Journal, 31(3), 329-334. doi:10.1080/10400419.2019.1631637

nodes.title: The Nature of Creativity and Ways of Measuring (Halie Yelle)
Bilingualism and Creativity: A Hidden Superpower? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: We already know that speaking another language can allow you to immerse yourself in different cultures and gain new career and educational opportunities. But could being bilingual increase your level of creativity?

typeData.textContent:
Could being bilingual (speaking two languages fluently) increase your level of creativity? Is it possible that bilingualism is a superpower that we could be overlooking when measuring an individual’s comparative level of creativity? According to many studies conducted over the past couple of decades, bilingualism might just account for some of these differences.

Bilingualism is generally defined as the use of multiple languages in everyday life on a regular basis (Grosjean & Li, 2013). However, there is quite a bit of variation in how an individual might acquire bilingual skills in their life. People may become bilingual early in life—children may learn two languages from birth, or acquire their second language later, such as when entering school—or, they may learn a second language to fluency in their teens or adult years (Dijk et al., 2018).

Research has shown that language and multiple experience with cultures may contribute to a richer environment than those of monolinguals (Wang & Cheng, 2016). As bilingual children often experience the customs, values, knowledge, and wisdom of two or more cultures, it is generally thought that this leads to a greater ability for creative processes. From a more linguistic standpoint, the language environments of bilingual children differ from those of monolingual children as they are exposed to two different vocabularies and two different conceptual systems underlying these vocabularies (Dijk et al., 2018). This increased ability to access a variation of linguistic knowledge may also explain why there might be a positive relationship between bilingualism and creativity.

In more controlled environments, bilinguals have been demonstrated to outperform their monolingual peers in problem solving, perceptual focusing, and the Simon task, which is a test measuring an individual’s interference/conflict resolution (Hommel et al., 2011). In several other studies conducted between 2007 and 2017, findings showed that highly proficient bilingual children showed a higher rate of inter-representational flexibility (i.e., links between components) in their drawings compared to their monolingual peers, outperformed their low-proficient bilinguals on the RAT (Remote Associates Test), outperformed monolingual peers on originality and ability to violate a standard set of category properties in the ATTA (Abbreviated Torrance Test for Adults) and IAC (Invented Alien Creatures) tests, as well as scoring better on thinking beyond standard categories and in creative problem solving in the ATTA (Kharkhurin 2011; Dijk et al., 2018).

However, these higher cognitive abilities don’t come without a price. In many cases, it has been shown that bilinguals consistently perform more poorly than their monolingual peers in verbal fluency tasks (Rosselli et al., 2000) as well as in verbal creativity (Kharkhurin, 2010). They are also shown to have performed worse on their elaboration and originality tasks in the ATTA test and perform significantly lower on the AUT (Alternative Uses Test), a task which involves listing all the purposes an object may have, with higher points awarded to not only quantity of responses, but also the degree of unique, original, or uncommon answers (Hommel et al., 2011).

Thus, it seems that bilingualism isn’t the magic creativity booster that we once thought it was. This does not mean that speaking another language to fluency has no positive influences on an individual’s intelligence or creativity, as was seen by and supported with many of the studies conducted on proficient bilinguals, but rather that there is a more complicated, not well understood relationship between the two. 

Works Cited:

Bernard Hommel, L. S. (2011). Bilingualism and Creativity: Benefits in Convergent Thinking Come with Losses in Divergent Thinking. Frontiers in Psychology.

Francois Grosjean, P. L. (2013). The Psycholinguistics of Bilingualism. International Journal of Applied Linguistics.

H.-C. Wang, Y. S. Cheng (2016). Dissecting language creativity: English proficiency, creativity, and creativity motication as predictors in EFL learners' metaphoric creativity. Psychology of Aesthetics Creativity and the Arts, 205-213.

Kharkhurin, A. V. (2010). Sociocultural Differences in the Relationship Between Bilingualism and Creative Potential. Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology, 776-783.

Kharkhurin, A. V. (2011). The Role of Bilingualism in Creative Performance on Divergent Thinking and Invented Alien Creatures Tests. The Journal of Creative Behavior.

M. Rosselli, A. A.-S. (2000). Verbal fluency and repetition skills in healthy older Spanish-English bilinguals. Applied Neuropsychology, 17-24.

Marloes Van Dijk, E. H. (2018). Bilingualism and Creativity: Towards a Situated Cognition Approach. Journal of Creative Behavior, 178-188.

nodes.title: What can affect our intelligence? (Tongtong Yan)
Measuring Intelligence with Binet's Scale (Claudia Le)

typeData.textContent:
While the eugenics movement focused on selectively mating people of desirable traits and weeding out those unfavourable, it originally came from measuring intelligence through IQ testing. Sir Francis Galton was the first person to invent some type of test for intelligence and his concept eventually led to many others developing a test of their own.

One of the next people to develop an IQ test was Alfred Binet, who was approached by the French government to develop a test to identify children who needed extra support in school. He eventually invented a practical test with tasks for children to complete which would correspond to their mental age. 

The children were presented with an object, which progressed to more complex items. Their mental was to be subtracted from their chronological age to calculate their IQ. It was quickly criticized by Stern though, who argued that a child's mental age should be divided by their chronological age and then multiplied by 100%. 

Binet ensured that his test measured skills that could not be learned in school but rather something that should come as as a second nature to the child. He additionally worried that the score coming out of his scale would lead to self-fulfilling prophecies. 

It was specifically stressed that Binet's test did not signify a level of intelligence but instead was to be used to identify child who needed extra support in schooling. However, Henry Goddard quickly introduced this scale to the United States, using it to indicate intelligence.

nodes.title: From the journal: why Flynn effect happens? (Jingxin Guo)

typeData.textContent:
Flynn effect is the phenomenon developed by Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray, which points out the fact that there is a “substantial and long-sustained increase in both fluid and crystallized intelligence test scores measured in many parts of the world from roughly 1930 to the present day.” (Baker et al., 2015) Many psychologists have proposed their hypothesis to explain why this happens. However, there is no saying that can be agreed commonly until now. 


Jakob Pietsching and Martin Voracek, psychology professors of the University of Vienna, had studied 100 years of IQ-test scores in 31 countries and published a paper called “One century of global IQ gains: A formal meta-analysis of the Flynn effect (1909-2013)” to illustrate their findings. They used solid evidence to refute some hypotheses as well as provided with their own opinions. So I’d like to share some interesting insights here.

	Education factor

A very popular proposal is that attending school can increase our IQ. Back in the 1960s, psychologists found that the IQ score of African-American children in some Virginia counties decreased at a rate of about 6 IQ points per year due to the closure of the public school. (Neisser, 1997) Pietschnig and Voracek also believe that education plays a role in our IQ but not as much as people say. They criticized “schooling is unlikely to account for the full extent of the IQ gains, and in particular the large gains for fluid IQ cannot be attributed to better education.” (Pietschnig and Voracek, 2015) 

	Nutrition

Nutritional deficiencies may limit body and organ functionality, especially for the first 2 years of life. (The Lancet, 2008) Also, Better nutrition can increase the size of head and brain. (Jantz et al., 2000) However, “Although genomic imprinting in principle would be suitable to explain IQ gains, this hypothesis remains difficult to test. Although influences of genomic imprinting cannot be completely ruled out, in the light of the observed fluctuations in the slope of IQ test score gains over time, this mechanism appears to be insufficient to plausibly explain the observed pattern in our data.” (Pietschnig and Voracek, 2015)

After analyzing these possible factors, Pietschnig and Voracek suggest that the prime candidate causes of Flynn effect would be the combination of both life history speed (such as factors that I’ve mentioned above) and a reduction of pathogen-related factors. It should be mentioned that they don't elaborate on every possible reason discussed in this paper, but it's still worth paying attention to those arguments that would help us to explain why the Flynn effect happens

References:
1.	Baker, David P.; Eslinger, Paul J.; Benavides, Martin; Peters, Ellen; Dieckmann, Nathan F.; Leon, Juan (March 2015). "The cognitive impact of the education revolution: A possible cause of the Flynn Effect on population IQ". Intelligence. 49: 144–58. doi:10.1016/j.intell.2015.01.003. ISSN 0160-2896.
2.	Neisser U (1997). "Rising Scores on Intelligence Tests". American Scientist. 85 (5): 440–47. Bibcode:1997AmSci..85..440N. Archived from the original on November 4, 2016.
3.	Pietschnig, Jakob & Voracek, Martin. (2015). One century of global IQ gains: A formal meta-analysis of the Flynn effect (1909-2013). Perspectives on Psychological Science. 10. 282-306. 10.1177/1745691615577701.
4.	"The Lancet Series on Maternal and Child Undernutrition". 2008.
5.	Jantz, R.; Meadows Jantz, L. (2000). "Secular change in craniofacial morphology". American Journal of Human Biology. 12 (3): 327–38. doi:10.1002/(SICI)1520-6300(200005/06)12:3<327::AID-AJHB3>3.0.CO;2-1. PMID 11534023.
